Body is medium plus and abounds with hops.  Mostly pine and tart grapefruit.  Sweet rounded full body excites my tounge for more and more.  Lingering spectacular aftertaste enrages me that I bought only one during my pre-lunch buying spree at half-time yesterday.  A bit longer body would be fantastic in this critter!  Another great beer from this brewery!

Tap: Poured a light hazy amber color ale with a small foamy head with good retention. Aroma consists of citrus notes with some floral hoppy notes also perceptible. Taste is also dominated by some citrus notes with some floral hoppy notes and some citrus notes with lightly sweet non-descript malt base. Body is about average with good carbonation. I really like the take on this one with nice floral aroma notes and limited bitterness.

Bottle acquired via trade with Thedrooid...Dan is a ROCK STAR!  14 karat pour with a small eggshell cap.  Bright grapefruit pith, tart orange rind, lemon zest and Ponderosa pine.  Earthy, dusty, dirty, peppery.  Quite complex and incredibly delicious!
Very hazy organish gold pour. The nose is super citrusy and piney. Very fresh. Spot on!

Bottled 2013-04-16 so relatively fresh (Whole Foods Tribeca). Pours a veiled golden with a huge white head that you could eat with a spoon. It leaves some of the most impressive lacing Ive seen in a while. Aroma is heavenly with intense grapefruit over a base of sweet syrup. Taste is dry with a moderate amount of bitterness. Mouthfeel is light and refreshing, quite a treat! Awesome!

5 ounce sample at the Freeport tasting room.  Very smooth and slightly bitter.  Good citrus notes.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pours a clear yellow with white head. great citrus aroma. citrus hops and orange grapfruit taste.

12 oz draft at the Pizzeria Paradiso - Dupont Circle, Washington DC.  The pour is a orange copper, hazed, with a well formed 1/2 inch white head.  The aroma is grapefruit and tropical fruit citrus hoppiness, grassy, some pine notes poking through as well.  There is a dry mineral malt present as well, though the hops are the main story.  The taste is the bright fresh grapefruit pineapple citrus hops, some pine grass, toasted malt, and a dry mineral in the back.  Nice balance of flavors.  The palate is light to medium bodied, soft natural carbonation and the dry mineral finish.  I preferred the Peeper slightly, though this was really tasty as well.

On tap 5 oz. pour at Max's in Fells Point, Baltimore, MD. 

Clear, golden pale amber with an off-white head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of passion fruit, tangerine, orange, grapefruit zest and a touch of pine. 

Taste of pineapple, lemon, grapefruit, tangerine, bread and grass. 

Medium/light body and medium/high carbonation with a thin, but smooth and foamy mouthfeel that is rather nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16.9oz bottle, thanks to Mike L. Date on bottle is 01/03/13. Shared. Totally hazy bright yellow-orange color. Nice thin off-white head, with good retention. Good spread of lace. Good, floral citrusy nose. Medium body. Lighter carbonation. Dry texture. Biscuity malt. Taste is light to moderate bitter, with a little zesty sweetness. Some citrus, nice light pine snap in the finish. Really nice pale ale. 4 months old, but it hasnt got that caramel malty sweetness that other pale and amber ales can get with the same amount of age.

16.9 oz bottle to snifter (thanks DrSilverworm). Bottled 1/3/13. Looks goos; a cloudy orange with sticky white lacing. Smells solid; bitter hops with some citrus zest and a semi-sweet backbone. Tastes like it smells with nice balance and a pleasant mouthfeel. Fairly dry on the finish for an APA. Good beer.

New Beer Distributors, NY 50cl ($8.25): Reviewer below me said that this was inexpensive... not anywhere in lower Manhattan (or Virginia for that matter), for sure. In any case, it pours a peachy orange with a big, fizzy, white head. Aroma is light grapefruit, ambiguous citrus, passionfruit, other tropical fruit, and some spruce-like stuff. Taste is light. Has one hit of bitterness around the middle to finish and then goes in for a lightly bitter fruity aftertaste. Very well-balanced. Proper hop content. Beers like this make APA a style worthy of existence. Completely not lazy. Except why you so expensive.

Bottle date: April 10, 2013. Poured May 6, 2013. Fresh, per the instructions. Purchased at Foodtown in Hamilton Heights, NYC.

When I looked this up on Ratebeer, I was not expecting such a high score. Good for the style, but actually not that impressive to me. Super fizzy, huge white head, weak champagne. Inexpensive - will likely buy again and re-rate.

Pours a cloudy apricot color with a huge, billowing white head.  Aromas of sweet tropical fruit, nectar.   Taste is a very clean and fruity nectar.  Not quite a god nectar, but pretty good.  finishes dry with a long bitter finish.  good.

1star = Not my cup of tea. 
2stars = Good 
3stars = Really Good 
4stars = Excellent 
5stars = Personal Hall of Fame

--you've been Dubbed.
Bottle->lager.  Light copper with thick white head.  Aroma: citrus and pine hops, citrus peel.  Taste: bitter citrus hops.  Straightforward and really good.

Bottle. Pours a yellow color with a moderate white head. Nose is super fresh with some floral and pine notes to it. Feels super light and easy to drink with some great smoothness. Very yummy and not too bitter.

Bottle. Cheers to Adam. The pours light amber with a tiny head. The nose is grapefruit. West coast citrusy hops. General tropical fruit. Light dough. The taste is tropical undergrowth. Grassy bitterness. Pacific tropical fruits. Mango and grapefruit. Light body, soft mouthfeel. Effortlessly drinkable stuff. Great beer.

Prominent citrusy nose. Super dry. Slightly grainy. Pale golden pour. Excellent white head with good retention. Moderately carbonated. 
Clean, dry, and fresh. Clean bitter finish,

Nice, should be in six-packs

Poured cloudy lemony orange with a frothy head of soft foam that would not go away.  Fell to some crags and  great lace.  Nose was pine, sweet citrus, tangerine, candy sugar, toffee malt, and a little pepper.  A little soap too. Taste was juicy citrus. Grapefruit rinds and pithy lemon, a tad astringent, and peppery.  Nutty toasted malt and finished with lots of floral, dry and bitter and somewhat thin.  It was worth trying and I liked it but not as much as everyone else.

500 ml bottle from albatross, also shared with czar. Last one on that crazy night ; cant believe I missed the bus and had to shell out $40 to go back home cuz of it! Well, it was worth the hassle. Lets do this: Pours a foggy whitish orange with a resilient white head. Flavor is tons of citrus, yeast, some cereals, touch of corn. Finish is mostly citrusy, with a good herbal punch to boot. Lingering citrus. Light body, low carbonation. Very flavorful, refreshing and easy to drink offering. Excellent for ending a tasting. And missing the last bus...

bottle from table and vine in Springfield, pours hazy bright orange with a 2 finger rocky white head.  Good lacing.  Nose is bright and fresh citrus with some tropical notes as well.  Very fresh and clean aroma.  Flavor is just outstanding.  Perfectly balanced malts and hops.  Nice clean pale grains and crackers without being overly sweet.  Hops are balanced throughout with nice citrus notes ending dry.  I could really drink this stuff all day and its a top 3 pale ale for me.  Great stuff.

500 ml, bottled 01-12-13. Thanks once again to Phatdog1. Hazy orange-gold with a huge head that settles to a lasting creamy disc. Nice aromas of grapefruit, pineapple, resin and orange toffee. Taste is fresh grapefruit, some orange zest, toast and a touch of honey. Light-medium body is watery and very soft, easy to drink. Finishes well to the dry side, but has enough malt body and floral character to remain balanced.
Grapefruit peel nose, moderate strength. Hazy amber, medium head. Dry lemon zest flavor, solidly bitter, but with little balance. Far too much carbonation. Dry and fizzy.

bottle shared by albatross, thanks! pours hazy pale yellow with a very nice white head, good retention and lacing. crisp pale malts, some bread crust, bold citrus, some tropical and few pine notes, floralness, freshly cut grass, bright green and citrus, hint of sweetness. bright carbonation, light body, very nice citrusy finish. very nice balance too. much enjoyed it!

500ml bottle. Pours a hazy golden orange color with small white head that fades quickly. Aroma of orange citrus with some tropical flavors blended in (Pineapple, lemon, and orange). Taste is grapefruit, orange, pine, with some bitter grassy hop notes.

Dry pale ale with perfect hoppy bouquet. Floral elements, crisp and subtle taste. Well balanced but its strength could be its undoing. Its taste is simple with no overabundance of hops or malt/extra gimmickry. I find it a strength but this subtle taste could also be called boring. Personally I love it.  A better execution of Ciscos Grey Lady.

Bottle from Phatdog1; another that Ive wanted to try for a while. Light golden pour, big, clingy head that stays around. Aroma is light but really nice hop. Flavor is moderately bitter, and balanced with the light malt. Finish is light lingering bitterness. A respectable pale, but not a favorite style.
UPDATED: AUG 23, 2013 Bottle shared at Voodoo Barrel Room Release. Hoppy aroma with a smooth balanced taste. A little bit thin but still quality.
Bottle. Cloudy light amber. Light lacing. Mild hop aroma. Slightly stonger hop flavor. Smooth and an easy drinker.

16.9 into a pilsner.  Pours a fine mesh of oranges, gold, and tan, with bronze taboot.  Head is full and encompassing, while frothy and substantial.  Aroma is hoppy, chalky, citrus, and piney.  A mild flow, maybe not the freshes batch, but still recognizably excellent.  Ive heard alot, just maybe picked the wrong one on the shelf.  Dirt soiled pine cones emerge after another whiff.  Still, an excellent drinker of a pale ale, soft pine experssions fold into a hop filled after bite while this conjurs thoughts of an ipa.  This is a good brewery.

Unfortunately this was a bit old when I tried it, almost 3 months. Luckily the beer held up surprisingly well. Juicy fruit and skunky hops in this one. Clean, light bodied malt background. The carbonation was just awesome, almost spritzy and very tight. Great mouthfeel. Cant wait to rerate this fresh in September.

Medium sized white head with good retention and lace. Hazy, gold colored brew. Gentle nose of citrus, flowery and light. Body is fairly light for a 6%er, lil resiny though and a bit juicy. Lotsa citrusy flavors,lil lemon, lil lime and a hint of pine. Malts are a little grainy and dry. Nice dry finish with a mellow bite. Nice stuff! Bottle from stateline liquors.

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. Another great IPA. Biggest difference from Zoe is more citrus in the hop profile and a dryer finish. Very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Half Time mail order.  This is an awesome beer.  Great hoppyness, with a nice citrus bite.  There was a sweetness thAt was surprising.  This beer was very refreshing.  Great head retention.  One of the best pale ales I have ever had.  Highly impressed with this beer and this company.  Glad I had the opportunity to try their beers
Pours clear amber with thick white head and plenty of lace, aroma is very citrus hops, lemon, pine. Taste is citrus, pine, very light malt, good bitterness, lively carbonation dry finish
#300 Rating for me! Wahoo! This brew starts with lots of citrusy notes, like limes and lemons! Kind of crazy! I really enjoyed this beer it reminds me of Sucks!
Bottle from Canals. This brewer is coming along nicely. This brew had a nice blend of caramel, orange peel and pine. Easy to drink. Refreshing.

Bottle from spence3208 pours golden amber capped by a thin cream colored head. Nose is subdued but has elements of tangerine and malt. Taste follows. Bitterness is more evident as it warms. An excellent apa and another great showing from this brewer.

Pours straw yellow with a big white head.  Citrusy, floral nose with just a bit of cat piss apparent.  Flavor is citrus peel and just a bit of pine.  A really, really nice Pale Ale that compares favorably to many IPAs and IIPAs.  This is a great little brewery--one of the best new discoveries Ive had thus far this year.  The New England brewery scene is finally starting to compete with the Midwest and West Coast!

Bottle via StateLine... Looks nice... Poured into a pint glass...Light orange in color, frosty white head that stuck around. Good lacing left on the glass. Yeast sediment in the bottom... Nose is fruity, piney. Taste great... just like I like my IPA and Pale Ales.... fruity, piney, little citrus, slight malt presence... Hop forward beer but not super bitter. Light body, good amount of Carbonation, crisp, refreshing, dry and easy to drink. Overall: Nice east coast pale ale!
Poured from a 500ml bottle. Bready, toast, hint of caramel, citrusy, pine, floral. This is a damn fine pale ale.

500 mL bottle from Total Wine in Virginia Beach, VA.  Yellowish-orange pour with a frothy almost white head.  Floral and grapefruit rind aroma mostly with faint caramel.  Great citrus and floral hop flavor with tons of bitterness.  Much more flavor than many IPAs yet this still comes across as a hoppy pale ale rather than a misnamed IPA.  Great beer!

Bottle... Hazy golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. The aroma is a fruity, earthy combination of tropical and citrus fruits underscored by a cat piss component. Medium-bodied with tingly carbonation. Both the flavor and finish are sweet and fruity with a modest measure of lingering bitterness. Bottle courtesy of ctipping!

Wow, where to begin with this stunning achievement?  The entire profile just speaks of utter freshness. The pour reveals a ruddy amber with a stout and luscious head floating on top.  The nose is full of ripe, rich, and spicy hops.  There is just enough malt to give it an appropriate backbone, but it never dominates-- like a baseline in a rock song.  You dont really know it is there, but without it, the presentation would be lacking.  The finish is remarkably smooth and balanced.   One of the best beers I have ever had.

16oz bottled November 16, 2012.  Right at 3 months old.  

Pours lightly hazy golden amber with a three finger foamy white head that leaves thick sheets of bubbly lacing and holds a great cap.

Aroma is grapefruit, lemon, very citrusy, floral hops, a hint dank and catty, some bready malt.  Good to very good strength.

Flavor is grapefruit, lemon, again very citrusy, hint of pine, mild bready malt, great bitterness and minimal alcohol on the finish.  Crisp and tasty.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, a little oily and sticky, good to sharp carbonation.

Excellent Pale Ale, right up there with the big boys from Three Floyds that Ive had.  Even right at the brink of the best-by date, this is fantastic.

received in trade from phatdog1.  My first Maine Beer Co. beer!  Aromas pine, cats ass (or barnyard), grass?  light orange pour with nice white head and long lacing.  Taste was some tropical fruit (someone said mango) with little to no malt sweetness followed by drying hops.  balaneced but you know the hops are there - not my favorite style and this is a high rating for me on an apa.  Thanks Craig!!
Magnifique pale ale aux accents dagrumes sucrés avec une amertume de pamplemousse rose. Buvabilité morbide.
On tap at Lord Hobo. Fresh, piney hops in the nose; some fruity notes as well. Crisp, clean, hoppy taste. Not biting or bitter at all. A damn fine APA.

Bottle at home. Pour is slightly hazy orange with a fluffy white head and great lacing. Big fruity aroma - pineapple, honey, grapefruit, oranges, somewhat piney and citrusy - very bright and inviting. Taste is zesty, piney, resiny, somewhat citrusy - straw and biscuit backbone - grassy and earthy with a medium bitter finish. Medium-to-light body with high carbonation. Very well-balanced; I wish I could get this stuff in quantity. Superb APA.
Citrus, pine, and spice in the aroma.  Flavor starts a little sweet, with citrus and pine bitterness in the finish.  Lots of flavor, but still pretty smooth.  All in all a really good beer.
Yes, amazing pale ale. Definitely deserving of a 4.0, which I rarely give out. Smooth and drank w/ GT2.

Bottle. Pour is gold, big white head, good retention/lace. Aroma of pine/grapefruit/floral notes, cracker malt, light caramel. Taste is piney/citrus hops, cracker, soda bread. Palate is crisp, lively carbonation, a bit oily, bitter finish. Very nice.

Hazy amber/orange color; Medium slight creamy body; Aroma of floral hops, pine, some fruit, & citrus; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel, pine hops, some mango, and citrus; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Quite good and refreshing.

Bottled 4 weeks ago.  Aroma of delicious pine, great grass notes, and a lemon rind citrus.  Intoxicating.  Pours hazy gold with a big foamy head.  Tastes yummy with grass, citrus and slight pine.  Refreshing but a little muddled.

One of the best APAs Ive had. Pours a light amber with a big head. The aroma has a ton of citrus, pine and some fruit. The flavor has the same qualities along with a nice malt backbone. Very dry and refreshing. I looking forward to having a few of these when the summer comes.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Ben on January 25th, 2013 after day 1 of Nerd Beer Epic Weekend.
Appearance: Pours a cloudy orange. 
Aroma: Aroma of orange, pine hops. 
Taste: Medium bitterness but not over doing it, orange citrus, very light malt.   
Palate:Medium light body, a quick finish.
Summary: After having a night full of belgian style beers and some stouts, I didnt want to call it a night before having some hops! And boy this doesnt disappoint. Just like with Peeper Ale, a well constructed APA that really has a nice hop profile. Dont know if I prefer Peeper or MO..guess Ill have to try again.  Thanks Ben!

Bottle - yes! Pours a hazy pale golden with a small white head and decent lacing. Aroma is grapefruit and passionfruit, very nice. Flavor is the same, with perhaps a touch of bready malt underneath. Lightly sweet and lightly bitter. Reminds me a lot of Zombie Dust, actually. Medium light body, extremely drinkable. Home Run APA.

From the 1 pint, .9 oz bottle. Bottled 01/12/13.  Pours a weak yellow orange with a 2 finger white head. Head slowly recedes leaving some lazy bits and pieces of lace. Fresh hoppy aroma loaded with grapefruit, pine resin and juicy tropical fruits. Underneath all this hoppiness is a semi sweet malt backbone. Perfectly balanced. Light to medium in body with sparkling carbonation. Easy drinkability. Lingering bitter finish. Another superb brew from Portland Maine.

500mL bottle.  Born on:  01/03/13.  I love the simplicity of the label.  Pours a hazy amber/orange body with a thick & fluffy beige head.  The pungent aroma features plenty of oranges, grapefruits, zesty citrus rinds, caramel, hints of doughiness, and some floral qualities.  Medium-bodied and crisp.  Light caramel and a touch of freshly baked biscuits upfront taste-wise.  Kinda grainy in the middle.  Juicy citrus and zesty rinds at the end.  A slightly dry finish.  Very pleasant and easy-drinking.
Draft and bottle. Orange hazy pour with light tan head. Sweet tropical fruit, and other ripe hop aromas. Flavor is fresh hop tones but not as vibrant, grassy and grapefruit tones.

Bottle from Half Time. Pours clear light copper with a creamy/bubbly white head. Aroma is lots of citrus - perhaps with a little floral. Med minus body. Flavor is light roast caramel with a good amount of floral/citrus. This is a flavorful, smooth beer. It finishes fairly dry and fruitily bitter. It is noticeable for its lack of harshness.
Thanks Seth!  Fruit bomb on the nose.  Huge citrus.  Love it!  Follows through with a nice mellow malt body.  Nice hop hit at the ends.

Bottle labeled 011213... 11 days old. Pours a hazy light orange/yellow with a one finger head that retains a nice film. Smell is wonderful... hoppy floral, citrus, orange, with a slight malty musk. Taste is also fantastic and doesnt disappoint. Good carbonation and medium body. My favorite from Maine Beer Co.

This beer poured a hazy light orange color with an off white head, yet very refined and clean looking at the same time.  Aroma was of fruity hops, mild bready grain, and light yeast notes.  Flavor was very crips and clean fresh hops flavors with pale grain that shows it face, but never takes over. Maine is doing some incredible things right now.

Draft at Capones.  Poured a cloudy gold with white head and some lacing.  Aroma is mostly citrus hops.  Light body with good citrus taste, some pine but fairly light.  Dont think this was their finest batch but still a really solid IPA

50cl bottle: pours a clear deep golden with a clingy-lacing froth of white head. Has a lightly sweet pale malty nose with  fresh resiny citrus hops. Starts with pretty good fullness and light malty sweetness well-balanced with good fresh grapefruity hops and bitter balance before a drier crisp bittersweet finish. True to style and enjoyable.
Very easy drinking pale ale...lots of aromatics, moderate body.  Mostly aroma for the hops, not a lot of bite in the body, but still very very good.

Bottle. Split with Janine for her birthday. Pours bright canary yellow with a thin, fuzzy white head that recedes to leave a small ring of fluffy lace around the edge of the glass. Aroma of freshly cut grass, clean soap suds, and some resiny, piney flourishes. Tastes of very fresh citrus fruits, along the lines of lemons and grapefruits, with some very grassy undertones. Almost no malt presence, which is a severely undervalued attribute in pale ales and IPAs these days, in my opinion. Medium bodied, but on the thinner side, which I also happen to enjoy very much, as it makes the beer infinitely more approachable, mellow, and drinkable. The cut of the hops more than balances the slightness of the body, which again, I enjoy immensely. This beer is very well done and I deeply appreciate Maine Beer Co.s commitment to both the environment, and more importantly, the freshness of their hoppy beers. This bottle had a bottled-on date clearly printed on its label and a recommendation from the brewers to consume it within 90 days of said date. I cannot stress enough how outrageously underutilized this practice is in the craft beer world. Thanks, Maine.

Bottle.  This fronts like some kind of hoppy, American wheat ... hazy and golden, with a stark white head of crated foam and a gristy, fruity aroma.  The drink has some of the same impressions ... certainly a bit gritty and earthy, but loaded with sweet, citrusy fruitiness.  Thats two "summer time" beers Ive popped today, in the middle of January.  Well, it is 60 degrees outside.  (#4900, 1/13/2013)

Bottle.  Pours clear gold, orange tints and a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is fresh and fragrant citrus and subtle tangerine hops, cracker and honey malt, apricot and pear esters.  Flavor is medium hops and bitterness, fresh fruity esters with light supporting malt and a dry finish.  Medium to light body, medium carbonation.

Bottle. Pours apricot gold with white head. Nose/taste of tropical fruit, grapefruit and citrus rind, mango, citrus and pale malt. Finishes dry and fruity rind - some resin/pine. Medium body. Well balanced. Bright and clean.

Bottle. Pours a clear pale gold body with a beautiful frothy white head that lasted nicely and left a nice lace pattern. The aroma is of nice delicate floral hops with a little pale bready malt. Really nice light tropical fruit notes from the hops as well. The tropical fruit notes really shine in the flavor as well, its like biting into a fresh mango. The malt is light, a little bit of doughy character, but mostly just stays in the back and allows the hops to shine. Light bodied and very easy drinking, it makes you want to take big gulps. Overall just a solid well made pale ale.

From notes.  Hazy orange body, large white head, solid lacing.  Nose is citric first, with some grassy and floral notes and some pale malts.  Taste is similar with some lemon, grapefruit, grass and pine.  Clean, medium bodied, good carbonation, moderately bitter finish.  Well rounded and developed.

Bottle from Spirits Berkeley. Pours out an attractive, slightly cloudy orange color with a nice white head. Aroma is of lots of citrus hops, fresh cut grass, light doughy malts and some fruit notes. Taste is very complex, clean and hoppy. Grapefruit, lemon zest, light grass, oily hop resin, with a light body that would make this one tasty session. Great beer.

Location: .5 L bottle from Sparrow-Downtown, 12/16/12


Aroma: The nose has lots of fresh hops, peach, mango, grapefruit, lots of resin, and some clean malts

Appearance: Pours a clear golden-orange color with a 2 inch sheet of white head that leaves drippy lace

Flavor: It tastes light-medium sweet, with tropical fruits, clean malts, and a medium-plus hop bitterness

Palate: The body is medium, it has a smooth, creamy, clean feel, tons of drinkability, and a nicely dry finish

Overall Impression: 
This is another Maine beer that I was really impressed by.  With Lunch and MO leading the way, Maine is quickly moving up my list of the top breweries in the country.  I really cant think of anything to complain about, this is almost exactly what Im looking for in an APA.  Heres the nicest compliment I can pay to an APA:  This is Alpha King-level for me.

Pours orange bodied with a lasting bubbly off white head.  Great smell, grapefruit and oranges. Smooth mouthfeel, great drinkability, creamy.  Very tasty orange creamy good hoppyness. The proof is in the taste and this is an excellent American pale.

From my Winter 2012 Secret Santa - Thanks! Pretty dang close to perfect, as far as Im concerned. Clean, crisp grapefruit hops, thin, but flavorful malts, easy drinkin, mouth-watering hops. I could drink A LOT of this. Thanks again!

Bottle.  Cloudy opaque golden--amber with a thick white head.  Aroma is grapefruit, tropical fruit, with a light biscuit malt background.  Taste is medium bitter, mild-medium sweet, near perfect balance.  Finish is dry and citrusy.  Medium bodied, well carbonated.  Another awesome beer from Maine Beer Company.

Pours a clear golden straw color with a huge white head that takes forever to recede and leaves lots of stickies on the side of the glass. Aromas of citrus fill the air as soon as I tilt the bottle toward the glass. Pine and resin with a hint of bread round out the nose quite nicely. The flavor is light bread, cracker and a hint of seltzer water with a nice pine and grapefruit flavor going on. Theres a solid shot of bitterness in this one, Im guessing because the body is a bit light to stand up to the massive hopping here. Moderate level of carbonation with a watery and resinous mouthfeel. This is a really nice pale ale, but I would have liked a bit more body especially with the heavy dose of hops in here.
500ml bottle-thin offwhite-hazy gold.  A-pineapple-tropical/lemon, some lt malt.  Crisp.  T-grapefruit rind/lemon rind-hop bite, drying, 2nd lt malt.  Crisp.

Bottle from Gianni - thanks!  Pours a light, slightly hazy golden color with a very large, rocky froth of white foam.  Aroma is clean, pungent citrus and bitter hops over a bone dry malt backbone.  Taste is on the bitter side with some pine and minor citrus (not as much as in the aroma) with no malt sweetness.  Clean, dry mouthfeel.  Sharp, slightly citrusy but mainly bitter pale ale with a clean malt backbone.  Very well done.
Awesome citrus aromas.  Very nice citrus flavors. Overall a very good pale ale.

Bottle. Amber pour with a tall, frothy tan head. Lovely floral hop aroma along with tropical fruit notes, peaches and citrus oils. Taste is floral hops, citrus, tropical fruit notes, sweet malt, light grains, soft caramel and peaches. Body is medium with a strong, bubbly carbonation and a pleasant lingering hop bitterness. Ends with more peaches, light apricot, tropical fruit, soft caramel, light malt notes and floral hops. Awesome!

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2013 Bottled November 10, 2012.
Appearance: What a beautiful frothy off-white head that towers above the beer with great retention and dissipates messy with lots of lacing, the downfall is the opaque amber hued body that looks murky and unappealing. Great looking beer nonetheless.
Aroma: This has a nice and assertive hop aroma with citrus and tropical fruits. Orange, pineapple and mango are balanced really well in the nose hinting at only mild bitterness balanced well with the sweetness.
Taste: The intro is nice and bready with light sweetness while the hops provide more flavor than bitterness adding an orange and pineapple. Bitterness is low and balanced well though the finish is a tad thin and dries up quick.
Palate: Medium body with bready texture thanks to the carbonation.
Overall: This is a very good pale ale, but it loses points because of the price. If this were cheaper I would buy it more often.

Pours a very pale color with a white foam head.  Aroma of grapefruit and pine.  Has a sweet citrus taste with a nice hop hit and zesty finish.  Clean, light and crisp.   Great aroma and taste for a pale ale.

Bottle 11/15/12.  Appearance:  clear golden pour with sudsy white head.  Aroma:  the very best smelling APA Ive ever had, huge beautiful sweet floral and citrus hop aroma with a touch of pine and biscuit.  Taste:  doesnt touch the power of the aroma but still has a little floral on the front with biscuit yeast in the middle and a fairly strong bitter finish.  Mouthfeel:  fairly light bodied with medium carbonation.  Overall:  One of the most floral smelling and bitterest tasting APAs Ive had.  Its like the taste and aroma flip-flopped their most pronounced attributes.  Im crazy impressed by Maine Beer Company with this and the two others Ive had (Zoe and Spring Peeper).
Draft at pony bar, lighter copper pour. Pine and spruce notes in aroma. Same flavor. Great bitterness. Extremely flavorful APA

Serving: 500 ml. bottle from Fire Works Leesburg.  It pours a hazy, light amber color with a small, off white head.  Nice light pine notes in the nose and on the tongue.  Subtle yeast and cracker as well.  Very light herbal and citrus as the beer warms.  Light to medium body with a lasting, medium bitterness.  Subtle, complex, and sessionable.  I am not sure what else you could want in a pale ale.  Highly recommended.

Bottle. Pours pale gold with a slight white head that leaves surprisingly heavy sheeting. Aroma is very fresh citrus with a touch of grass. Taste is a slightly bitter with a pineapple bite. Bit of a resiny finish. Different enough to stand apart from their Peeper ale and slightly more balanced with a bit more pronounced flavor.

Half liter bottle form Wine Warehouse, Charlottesville. Pours a slightly hazy pale amber color with a large foamy tan head. Good head retention. Big citrus hop notes, very fresh, with some toffeeish malts. The taste is herbal, citrus and candied citrus hops. Lots of grapefruit. Again, very fresh. Mild caramel malts. Thin-medium bodied. Refreshing. Very nice APA.
Not to sound like a fan boy but these guys can brew. Love their beers love their price point. Hoppy, crisp and light, very easy to drink. Pairs well with  pub food

11/14/12. 500mL (ish) bottle thanks to Lukaduke! Hazy golden pour with a soapy, frothy off-white head. Huge fresh hop aroma with tons of citrus, tropical fruits, and dankness. The flavor has a nice subtle hop bitterness with the flavors listed above along with a hint of sugar and biscuits. Very nice!

[bottle]
Herbal, mango and cat pee hops aroma with some faint base malt in the background. Foggy dark gold under a lasting, rocky, white head. Sweet, tropical hops flavour with lots of cat pee and a faint base malt backbone. Subtle bitterness well-balance with a tingly sweetness and a dry finish. Medium carbonation, almost clean finish, light to medium-light body.

Tap. Slightly hazy yellow orange with a thin bubbly white head. Aroma is lovely with bright grapefruit, light resin, a hint of pine and a soft light fruit sweetness. Flavor is less aggressive, but still solid with grapefruit pine and resin.  Lighter body with vibrant carbonation.

Bottle. This is a great American Pale Ale. If anything it's a bit hoppy, but that's what Maine Beer does. Aroma is very citric. Pours a vibrant yellow orange with a lasting pure white head. Very hop dominated beer with layers of grapefruit and pine. Finish is very drying and satisfying. Wonderful. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Excellent, sessionable, well balanced beer!  Very happy to find it here in SW Virginia.

16.9 oz bottle- pours clear medium yellow w/ small white head of fine carbonation. Aroma is fantastically toned down hops, fruit, & caramel. Taste is the same. This tastes like it would be the worlds best cracker. Mouthfeel is medium & finish is light lingering hop bitterness. Very nice

Bottle from decicco's. Fantastic floral hop nose. Extremely good pale ale. Fantastic.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bottle into a brandy snifter from a bottle so graciously provided by Lukaduke. Thanks again! Pours a copper color with a soft white head of foam with good retention. The aroma has that super fresh hop note to it that Lunch had. So grassy and floral and wonderful. The taste is more of that grassy hop bitterness. Man, this is great. I really enjoy this one.

Bottle shared by lushawn- thanks again, Shawn! Consumed from bottle. Notes of tangerine citrus, tropical fruits, pine, caramel malts, and fresh cut grass. Light-bodied, with a clean, dry mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Really nice. Need to get another fresh bottle so I can do a proper pour.

Bottled last week. Blond opaque pour with thick and creamy head. Aroma is tropical fruits (peaches, pinneaples especially) forward with complementing honey and bready malts, some flowers too. Light bitterness, packed with sweet white fruits, honey and a lemon finish. Carbonation is soft, body medium-full. This is a very tasty APA but not very sessionnable.

Bottle about a month old.  Big floral, herbal, and citrusy aroma here. This is clean and refreshing. The pour produces a slightly hazy golden color thats topped with a lasting off-white head. This is medium to even light-bodied with herbal, grassy, and citrusy flavors.  Some pine too. I didnt think there was really much of a malt influence but other ratings disagree. Dry finish. Great stuff. A little different than their Peeper Ale but I like the two about the same.

Bottle from 12-Aug-2012. Pours a golden tan with nice head that leaves lacing. Nose is brown plesant with beautiful smells of pale malt and resinous hops. first sip is similar finish not not bitter just right. good stuff.

500ml bottle in a shaker.  Pours copper with a lacy, cream-colored head.  Aroma of citrusy and floral hops, a good amount of caramel malts, and a little toast.  Flavor the same.  Average texture.  A good beer for the style.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2012 Bottle dated 8/12/12 so three weeks old! Pour has a dark golden color and a nice thick one finger white head that retained very well. Aroma just kicks out the hop goodness. Tropical fruit, grapefruit, dry citrus zest, resins, and a core of lightly sweet malt under it all. Mouth feel is light and crisp and there is plenty of strong carbonation. Flavor is incredibly smooth delivering all the hop flavors. Bitterness picks up a bit, citrus, resins, mild sweetness, and a good deal of malt for a pale ale. This is really an ipa but it is super tasty none the less.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2012 Bottle from Desrosiers in Freeport. Amber pour, small frothy head. Unfortunately I think this bottle was a bit old; could detect hints of the lovely light pine, grapefruit, and hints of nectar fruit that I think this beer must have been rife with when fresh, but too much caramel malt, not even remotely as fresh as I imagined. Still, tasty. Rerate 11-6-12 on draft at Churchkey. Much fresher with beautiful simcoe green character and lovely grapefruit as well. Much much better when nice and fresh.
500ml bottle shared by jsprime. light orange with a white head. pretty much a perfect APA. nice and lean and sessionable. very thoughtful hopping. very well done.

500 ml bottle from Pinocchios. Pours a golden amber color with a big white head.  Aroma is hoppy, citrus, mango, pineapple.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, cereal, hippy, citrus, light pine, with a light, bitter finish.  Very tasty.

Pours a cloudy orange with a huge white head. Very nice aroma of floral hops, pine, orange, a little sweetness. Taste is very hoppy with alot of pine, citrus, a little grapefruit, malts. Mouthfeel is medium with nice level of carbonation. All in all one of the best APA ive had so far!

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2013 Bottle @ Steves house, courtesy of lukaduke. Hazy, dull brownish orange appearance with an off white head. Spicy, lightly dank, a bit resiny, floral hoppy, a bit toasty aroma. Quite resiny, herbal, floral, cracker, biscuity malty, pretty crisp flavor. Great fucken beer.

Bottle shared with Charlie at the Cabin, NH. Pours clear, vibrant gold with a large, white foam head. Big, ripe orange nose with some pine, honey, grass, apple and toasted pale malts. Medium sweet, rich flavor with loads of piney bitterness, citrus, orange, florals, some toasty breads. Medium to full bodied with average, creamy carbonation. Dries out lightly to finish, with lots of sticky and resinous pine, sticky grass, some cedar wood, hints of caramel and honey sugars, pale malts. Great balance. Superb.

Bottle. Pours cloudy gold, with a large, white head. Aroma is citrusy hops and sugar. Flavor is citrus,  hops, pine, and a floral finish. Medium body. 
Highly enjoyable.

Lightly hazy amber color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of pine, floral hops, toast, and some citrus fruits. Taste of pine, grapefruit, citrus, light sweetness, and a hoppy finish. Tick score represents an old bottle sample.

I worked with a young lady named Mo in Sierra Leone, I wonder if this beer was named after her?  Bottle. Hazy golden yellow color, large white head with good retention and solid fluffy lacing.  Aroma of Christmas wreaths. Taste is piney, floral and bitter. A beautiful thing.

In short: A superior piney pale ale
How: Bottle 500ml.  Consumed very fresh a few weeks after bottling date
The look: Mostly clear golden body topped by a medium off-white head
In long: Nose is scented pine-tree hops (borderline perfumy).  Taste has a nice medium-toasted biscuity malt backbone with sparse dried caramel.  There is a nice fruitiness (mangos, bananas, more) that seems to be coming from the yeast/fermentation as much as from the hops.  Also light notes of acidic citrus fruits and perfume.  Pine-tree and cedary hops finish with a medium bitterness of short duration.  If it wasnt for the slightly perfumy aroma and flavor this would be a truly excellent beer.  Maine Beer Brewery is really a an east-coast rising star.  And one has to admire Maine Beer Brewing for their support of environmental organizations, these guys are really trying to make a difference while you are just sitting there, wasting your time reading my rating, youre pathetic.

50cl bottle, Campground Brewdown.  Medium white head, cloudy apple juice body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, orange/floral, some grapefruit.  Taste is moderately sweet, orange, some floral, grapefruit, bread.  Light-medium body, light resin.

Bottle at James a few months ago. Thanks James. Strange, awesome brass-brown sort of color with pretty big white head and uneven bubbles. Smell/taste are both extremely fresh pine hops. Clean finish with not a lot of aftertaste.

500 ml bottle purchased from Capones, sort of an odd size for an American craft. Poured a honey brown body with a large frothy off white head that left average lace but a large dense center of foam that never dissipated. Aroma of honey topped bread, orange marmalade, citrus rinds, bran cereal. Medium bodied with stronger small bubbly carbonation, a dry bitter finish and a lingering hop aftertaste. Flavor is sweet citrus pulp and rind, toast, tangerine, grapefruit, apricot. Solid beer.
Traded bottle. Pours a nice cloudy, amber color with a massive, foamy white head. Huge piney aroma with hints of pineapple. Nice sweet flavor that reminds me of ruby red grapefruit. Very well done.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2013 Bottle, pours hazy copper, massive white head with insane lacing streaks.I agree with the last dude, American ipa all the way. Juicy aromas of bubblegum, grapefruit juice, resinous pine, lemons, grass and just a hint of biscuity malt. Taste was just as impressive with fresh citrus hops getting most of the attention. Other notes of earthy malts, mango, caramel and pine. Smooth bitter finish, incredibly sessionable, all around an amazing hoppy pale.

An American Pale in name only.  This would compete with any IPA.  Full-on hop aroma, balanced and nearly creamy mouthfeel.  Taste is not as bitter as the aroma would lead you to believe.  Highly drinkable.  Extremely well-made.  Maine Beer Company is something to watch.  Closely.

Tap at Meadhall. Translucent golden pour with a dense white head served in a wine-style chalice. Very hoppy nose. Floral, resin, and tons of bitter citrus. Taste is very floral with a restrained resin bitterness that wants to come forward but keeps itself in check. The malt is weaved in well but pretty much goes unnoticed because of the big hop fragrance and flavors. The glass is well coated and the brew is slippery in the mouth. A very floral, über-hoppy pale ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml bottle poured a clear golden amber with a lasting creamy offwhite head. Aromas of biscuit, skunk bud, earthiness, grapefruit, orange zest and pine resin. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of bread, orange zest, pink grapefruit and light pine with a crisp dry lingering citrus finish.

a bottle of Maine . Super hazy pale orange color with a substantial foamy head. Aroma is all grapefruit, fresh cut grass and whole grain. Taste is more malty with light bitter. Palate is fairly full for a pale ale giving this a hefty real ale likeness. MBC doing it again.

Pours a light copper color with frothy three finger head. Aromas are pineapple, pine and a touch of sweet grapefruit.  Dont let the pale ale fool you, MBC brings the hop flavors ! On the palate this one hits the mark, great mouthfeel and carbonation to carry the balanced flavors on a journey of excellence.  Grapefruit, pine, mango... ride the toasty malt flavors to completion !

Poured from a 500ml bottle into a pint glass. Bottled on 6-25-12 which puts this at just over two weeks old. Pours a murky brown. Pretty messy, kind of like pond water. Must be something about Maine Beer co because Peeper was like  that too but lighter.  Lots of exceedingly frothy head and lacing.  Mild grassy and piney aroma. mouthfeel is moderate. Taste is mostly pine with some dirt, ink, dandelion and malt. Overall a decent beer but I just don't really like MBCs yeast.  It just has a dirty flavor that I don't care for. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

crazy grapefruit aroma and flavor, bitter, one dimensional ish, but that one dimension is amazing.. super grapefruit all over, medium body clear pale amber golden lacing for days... outstanding beer... Addition: originally had on draft, now out of a fresh bottle, piney resinous malty murky minimal citrus notes, leads me to believe my original rating was a mislabeled keg... Very good, but entirely different than I remember in a mildly disappointing way...

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2014 Bottle. Pours a hazy amber with a slight head. Another good beer from Maine Beer Company. Great hop taste and aroma. Easy drinking pale.

Update 8/11/14: On draft at Portland Lobster. Forgot how good this beer was and even better fresh on tap in Maine
Draft: pour is hazy orange with thin white head, hoppy aroma, taste is hoppy, citrus, very dry finish

On tap at Atwoods Tavern - Cambridge, MA. Clean, bright, electric dank and green-yellow hop aroma. Fresh. Flavors bounce equally well. Theres a drier, grassier almost pale-tobacco-like flavor, with some white figs, golden raisins, and clean mint tea. Body is impeccable. I love Maine Beer Co hoppy beer. So straightforward, but complex and luscious. Alive. Prickly. Fun to drink and hop-satisfying. Better than Peeper?
On Draught. Big Tropical hop aroma, Again more Tropical hops on the palate, Grapefruit, Lemon, Mango. Backed by some earthy malt notes. Clean tasting from start to finish. Very nice

Great session ale, come to the railroad bar and grille and ask for Rochelle.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A blend of different styles put together really well. A light body, some spice and floral notes of a saison, some hops and a long finish. Lighter than a pale, spicier than a saison. Very tasty.
From the tap poured an amber color with a small amount of head.  Nice light bitter hoppy flavor with a quick finish.

Pours a clear golden with a medium creamy white head.  Aroma is light with nice tropical fruit...mango...and some stonefruits.  Flavor follows suit for the most part...stonefruit and also grapefruit with a touch of spice.  Mouthfeel is light and silky with a dry, tropical fruit finish.

Floral and grassy. Hazy, yellow, off-white irregular head, good lace. Very dry, hoppy start that continues in the finish, light fruity, mainly grassy, rather bitter. Balanced, pleasant.

Pour from a bottle thanks to my friend Tim in Portland. Color is golden with a modest white head. Aroma is wonderful and full of fresh grapefruit and lemon. Prickly carbonation in your mouth. Flavors follow suit with peach, bitter hops, grapefruit, tangerine, and lemon. Finish is balanced and hoppy. Really liked this beer and definitely worth trying and would like a fresh one again.

Appearance:  Pours a deep copper with a bright white head that leaves behind thick lacing.

Aroma: Grapefruit, mango, pineapple,  magic.

Taste: Tangerine, dry malt, earthy bitter finish with a short duration.

Overall:  Im a huge fan of the ultra flavorful pale ale. This is bright, hoppy and full of character that sets it apart from others. Very well done.
Bottle with James, Andrew, and Maggi. Hazy amber pour. Nice grapefruit nose with some pinecones. Prickly holly flavor. Slight honey finish but a little thin.
Bottle with Dallas, Maggi, and James.   Awesome murky color... Golden and. Brown, super hazy.  Delicious line flavor, some tangerine, tart and bitter.  Fantastic American pale.
Draft. Pours cloudy copper with very little head. Aroma is very floral.. A ton of pine. Taste is bitter for an apa. Finish is smooth and palate is full. really killer for the style.

Big thanks to chowdahead for sending this bottle out my way. Served in a Maine Beer wine glass.

Pours a clear light apricot color with a nice white head and a pretty good ring of white lace as the head falls. Good cap and collar throughout.

The nose carries some faint tropical fruits and a bit of citrus. Light mango. Just a touch of pale malt lingering in the background for some depth. The flavor has the same elements with a bit of orange peel sneaking in. Nice and light. Light body with crisp carbonation and a slightly-bitter dryness through the finish.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2013 My Bottom Line:
Piney hop cologne seeps from this frothy American Pale Ales lean body, building salient bitterness softened by lightly bready yeast.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A superb foam mushroom rises atop the hazy amber.
-This may not be as complex as Hill Farmsteads Edward, but it is a mighty beautiful APA nonetheless.
-I would leave the sediment out, especially for your first pour. It tends to obscure some of the hops brightness.
-Hops also contribute some citrusy fruitiness.
-Drinkability is very high; this brew is relatively dry and fluffy, nearly quenching.

Bottles.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of malt, hops, citrus, grass, mango, tangerine, and other tropical fruits.  Poured orange in color with a large, creamy, rocky, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Very good to excellent lacing. Flavor is medium sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of malt, hops, tropical fruit, and citrus.  Medium body.  Lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, citrus, hop, tangerine finish is lightly dry.

Aroma of pine at first, and then a smooth, light perfumey spring scent that is so soft and velvety in the nose. Pours cloudy and murky dark lemon with a decent bright white head. The flavor of citrus, lemon, with no bitterness of the hops as you would expect on a perfect medium body.

Bottle.  Pours a hazed copper tinged amber with a large dense off white head.  Smells wonderful, big bold citrus and resinous grapefruit.  Pungent but not overpowering.  Medium bodied, smooth and gentle.  Nice earthy malt backbone with a good amount of bitterness.  Finishes with a lingering and strong bitterness.  Very palatable and easy drinking.  Liked this a lot.

another really solid offering from maine beer co, this is a really good pale ale. i feel that my actual like of MBC is greater than the sum of my ratings numbers, they seem low in comparison to how fondly i remember these beers. great stuff, never pass up a a chance to try anything fresh from these guys. impressive.

Lushawn you glorious gentleman you, thanks for this.

Pours a hazy golden color with a big billowy white head with tons of lacing on the glassssssssssssss.

The aroma is hoppy & pungent & very fresh smelling. There are some very nice herbal and dank qualities with some beautiful lime rind and grapefruit as well. 

The flavor is grapey up front with a lot of fruit forward hops. The beer is dry and has a good bit of peppery and citrus flavor. The lightly toasty malt is crisp and clean and constantly in the background. 

Fantastic.

Bottle... Hazy light copper pour,two finger white head,excellent lace. Sweet malt aroma with notes of citrus fruit,mango and pineapple. Sweet, bready,nutty malt flavor leads to a pleasant citrus fruit and resin bitterness. Medium bodied and carbonation.Finish is dry with a lingering bitterness. Simple and delicious.

Fresh bottle.  Pours an intriguing pinkish hue though the color in the glass doesnt show much of that.  Huge billowy head.  High marks for label design and brewer identity conveyed through it.  Very full floral and light peach hop aromas, not overly sweet.  Flavor is bittersweet pine and fruity on a super fresh soapy mouthfeel that is light and dry giving away the pale ale identity. Another phenomenal beer from MBC.

Bottle shared by B3C. Poured a hazy amber color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate sour citrus hop and malt aroma. Medium body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. I would had this with freinds.

Is it lunch with a different label?  These guys continue to impress me with their fresh hop flavors lovin it .... Hazy golden amber pour sticky lacing and off white head .... aroma is hoppy citrusy lemony with a bit of biscuity malts .... taste is of bitter rindy lemony citrusy hops, very frresh citrusy punch and a nice caramel malty biscuity backbone ... reminds me of daisy cutter .... finishes dry and with a nice bitter hop .... excellent pale ale could drink this all day

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2012 Bottle split with pat. Pours a hazy amber with crazy white lacing. Aroma is fresh bitter hops and some citrus. Mouthfeel is okay with fresh bitter citrus, light pine and floral notes. Super fresh and drinkable. Dear god.

Bottle thanks to lushawn, thanks man!  Pour is pretty much clear copper with a medium, soapy white head. Aroma is citrus hops, faint resinous hops, and a light cereal malt backbone. Maybe a few floral notes as well. Very straight forward and clean. Flavor is very true to nose with notes of citrus hops (grapefruit mostly with some passion fruit notes) and a light cereal malt backbone. Finish is clean with more citrus hop notes and a light mineral note. Very easy to drink and very clean. Solid pale ale for sure.

16.9 oz bottle.  Glowing yellow brown with a marshmallow creme head.  Nose is grapefruit, grass, lemon peel and cat.  Medium body with an airy tingle.  Taste is lemon-lime, tangerine and pine with a touch of honey.  Finish is lightly bitter and bready with spicy herbal hints.  A softer Alpha King.  SO nice.

50 Centiliter bottle.  Pours turbid dark straw with an aggressive 3-finger uniform, well-retained white head.  Nose is....<assume the voice of former NCAA football commentator Keith Jackson> oh my God Bob Griese lemme tell ya bout the nose...this is a nose that Bear Bryant would forfeit a game to Tuscaloosa State to crave more of.  Huge pineapple, grapefruit, tangerine, mango, pine needles, spruce, black pepper, resiny sticky wet hops.  A 10 for the nose easily.  The taste is assertively hoppy, crisp, with a big tangerine and pineapple forefront, then some sweet orange marmalade and black pepper notes at mid-palate, and a bit more malt in the finish.  This is truly one of the hoppiest APAs I have yet had, and would hold its own with the big hoppy IPAs in a blind tasting. The only negative is that it is a bit malt-light, but thats a minor beef.

Pours copper gold with a fluffy white head.  Nose is bright hops, more hop forward than Peeper and Lunch, more sweet tropical fruit and candied citrus peel.  As with all of Maines pale ales, this is pretty dry and balanced in the mouth.  Fresh cracked grain, bitter throughout, lots of fruit character hiding beneath.  Nice.

Pours deep gold into a shaker. Bright white head with excellent retention recedes leaving spot lacing to coat surface. Biscuit and resin aromas. Sweet bready malt upfront turning to resin in the lasting finish. Extremely well balanced American leaning to English pale ale.

(500 ml from Oak Street Provisions) Hazy pale gold-yellow, slight amber hue. Tall off-white head that slowly recedes. Big, fresh, hoppy citrus-grapefruit aroma with caramel and vanilla underneath. Mouthfeel smooth and full. Thick, messy lacing left behind. Flavor is hop-forward, lots of fresh grapefruit over lighter caramel and vanilla. Sweet and smooth, no tongue-scraping harshness. Very fresh and vibrant.
These guys know how to brew one hell of a pale ale. Lighter in color than the peeper, same hop notes with a little easier finish. Drinkability is very high.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2013 huge beautiful aromas of soft tropical fruit, citrus and pine.  pristine rustic white head, very fluffy and thick and attractive.  Flavors follow the nose, but strong bitterness up front that fades quickly leaving a pleasant crispness.  dry finish, superior drinkability.  almost a perfect beer.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2013 fresh bottle.  excited about this, as hoppy 6.0 % abv pale ale is one of my favorite beer styles, and this is a brewery that has definitely delivered in the past.   pours a hazed bronzed orange hue with a big frothy long lasting white head leaves some tight layered lace.  aroma of big juicy clementines, tangerines.   touch of pineapple.   notes of grassy resin.   nice.  real nice.   pleasant toasted malt backdrop.  some caramel and clean pineapple sweetness.  awesome balance.   nice and dry.  clean.   great body.   just an awesome all around beer.    be nice if it was less than $7  a 500ml bottle.  but happy it exists!
Intense intense aroma,maybe the best smelling beer ever. The flavors are more muted and less intense. I found it supremely drinkable and a great beer between the peeper and lunch

Bottle at Moeder Lambic, thanks Jean. 
Hazy golden coloured with a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of hops and pine needles with notes of chalk and citrus.
Fruity flavour of hops, grass and citrus.
Dry hoppy finish.

500mL. Pours clear, deeper gold with a powerful, rocky, off-white head. Ice cream float retention. Big lace. Fresh pineapple and cantaloupe nose with small sugar, sweet grapefruit, Valencia orange juice. Taste is fabulous: nutty, doughy, quenching, pineapple and orange juice. Mild fresh Hawaiian sweet rolls. Beautiful, fresh, quenching palate. Refreshing. Finish is mildly nutty, so soft and subtle. This brewery really knows how to make a masterpiece of a session beer. Hallelujah.

50 cl bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is smooth mango, peachy and citrusy. Mellow peachy, mango, light yeasty and smooth floral to fruity. Bitter and crisp hoppy into a smooth fruity finish.

I have learned by now that Maine Beer Co knows a thing or two about aromas. A big spruce nose right off the bat. Nice frothy head to this slightly hazy light copper brew. This is very, very smooth. Not sticky like a million other pale ales out there, but yet plenty flavorful. Lingering spice notes. Very good stuff.

IMPOSSIBRU!  Ridiculously clean and fresh tasting APA.  Notes of columbus and citra hop dominate with a very clean crisp finish.  So much floral and citrus hop flavor.  These guys are masters of hoppy beers.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2015 Now this Is a mother fucking pale ale. Super hoppy aroma and flavor with light bitterness. Colombus and citra type flavors. This is epic.
